result.execSummary:
The defendant Bronson D. Anderson was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Battery [Modifiers: Repeater], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 940.19(1).
  • Bail Jumping-Felony [Modifiers: Repeater], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(b).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Concurrent with: Concurrent with any other supervision/probation/extended supervision he is currently on.

miscConds.notes: Defendant is objecting to the figure that has been proposed by the victim witness coordinator.  Court will proceed under 973.20(13)(c) #4.  Deferred to the Circuit Court Commissioner who shall conduct a hearing on the matter and submit a record thereof within 60 days of the date of the referral. ***Findings of Law: Restitution is determined to be $2,213.39.

Pay costs.    If probation is discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil Judgment will be entered against the Defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Per Wisconsin Statute, funds from prison accounts may be used for obligations in accordance with prison policy not to exceed 25% of gross.
AODA unless has one completed within the last year and that agent is satisfied and provides necessary information for alcohol treatment.

Defendant to maintain absolute sobriety.
Do not possess or consume alcohol or be on premises where alcohol is served/sold as its primary business except within scope of your employment.
Do not possess/consume controlled substances without a valid prescription and be taken according to the prescription.
No contact, direct or indirect, with Nicole Grawey.
Engage in any other counseling deemed appropriate.

miscConds.notes: Comply with all conditions set forth in Count 1.

Attorney Maris Rushevics in court. David R. Knaapen appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Atty Knaapen makes statements as to the status of the motion to withdraw the plea.  Parties have discussed and Atty Rushevics will withdraw his motion.  
State will amend the narrative in the complaint, and the sentence would remain unchanged. 
Atty Rushevics concurs.  Makes additional statements.  The only change will be to modify the language in the probable cause portion of the complaint.  Withdraws his motion at this time. 

BY THE COURT: 
Motion is withdrawn and Atty Rushevics will be attorney of record.
Motion hearing on October 13, 2014 at 08:30 am.

records.descr: Notice and acknowledge of def voting ineligibility

records.addlTxt:
Plea questionnaire/Agreement filed.
Prosecutor states plea agreement.
Attorney for Defendant concurs with agreement stated.

Defendant enters a plea of: NO CONTEST to Counts 1 & 2.

Court questions Defendant regarding plea.
Court informs Defendant of Constitutional Rights. Court advises Defendant of Elements State must prove for the Charge.
Court questions Attorney for Defendant.
Court finds Defendant's Plea is freely, voluntarily and intelligently made.
Attorney stipulate that there is factual basis for the charge(s).
Defendant agrees to prior conviction. 

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charge(s).
Court finds the defendant guilty Counts 1 & 2 as repeat offender contrarty to the statutory section stated therein.  Clerk directed to enter Judgment of Conviction this date.

Atty Knaapen files Victim Impact Statement with the Court and Atty Rushevics as well as the Restitution Summary. 
Atty Knaapen makes sentencing arguments to the Court.  Asks the bond to be held and applied to the restitution.
Atty Rushevics makes sentencing arguments to the Court.  Restitution is disputed. Requests a hearing. 

BY THE COURT: 
Count 1 - 
Sentence Withheld. Placed on Probation for a period of 3 years, concurrent to any other supervision/probation/extended supervision he is currently on:
AODA unless has one completed within the last year and that agent is satisfied and provides necessary information for alcohol treatment.
Defendant to maintain absolute sobriety.
Do not possess or consume alcohol or be on premises where alcohol is served/sold as its primary business except within scope of your employment.
Do not possess/consume controlled substances without a valid prescription and be taken according to the prescription. 
Obtain/Maintain fulltime employment.
Engage in any other counseling deemed appropriate.
No contact, direct or indirect, with Nicole Grawey.
Pay costs. 
Restitution - Defendant is objecting to the figure that has been proposed by the victim witness coordinator.  Court will proceed under 973.20(13)(c) #4.  Deferred to the Circuit Court Commissioner who shall conduct a hearing on the matter and submit a record thereof within 60 days of the date of the referral. 

Count 2 - 
Sentence Withheld. Placed on Probation for a period of 3 years, concurrent to count 1 and all other cases. 
Comply with all conditions set forth in Count 1. 
Pay costs. 

ANY BOND POSTED IN 12CF391 WILL BE TRANSFERRED TO 14CF166 AND HELD UNTIL THE TIME THAT RESTITUTION HAS BEEN RESOLVED.
IF THERE IS NO RESTITUTION, BOND TO BE APPLIED TO THE COSTS AND BALANCE RETURNED TO THE POSTER. 

Parties are to review the jail credit and submit a stipulation and order.  Then the credit would only apply in the event that his probation is revoked. 
Court advises Post-Conviction rights.

State files Information.
Defendant received copy of information.
Defendant waives reading of information.

Defendant waives right to preliminary hearing. 
Court questions defendant regarding waiver of preliminary hearing. 
Court questions Attorney.
Court finds the defendant has freely, voluntarily and intelligently waived the preliminary hearing. 
On the defendants waiver of the preliminary hearing, Court determines, based on the facts contained in the complaint, there is sufficient probable cause and binds the defendant over for trial.

Defendant Bronson D Anderson in court with attorney Maris Rushevics. David R Knaapen appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Both files: 12CF391, 14CF166

Atty Knaapen moves to dismiss 12CF391 as they have refiled this case under the 14CF166 file.  Provides written dismissal to the Court. Anticipates an initial appearance. 
Atty Knaapen states the plea agreement.  Has complied with Victim Notification Statutes.  Victim is not present but does have a written statement. 
14CF166:
Attorney/Defendant received copy of criminal complaint.
Court informs defendant of charges and maximum penalties.
Attorney/Defendant waives reading of complaint.
